Good morning.

Donald Trump told a crowd of tens of thousands that he ‚Äúhates‚Äù his opponents at a memorial for Charlie Kirk, despite his widow saying she forgives the man charged with fatally shooting her husband.

items.title: Weather tracker: Flash floods and landslides wreak havoc in California
items.content_html:
Two-year-old boy dies and homes buried as remnants of Tropical Storm Mario bring downpours and thunder

Flash flooding and landslides led to the death of a two-year-old boy in California in the US last week, after heavy rainfall followed on the heels of Tropical Storm Mario further south. The storm skirted the Pacific coast of Mexico with minimal disruption, eventually dissipating to the west of Baja California on Tuesday, but the remnants went on to cause havoc on Thursday. Residual moist air from the tropical storm was drawn north-east towards California, bringing heavy downpours and thunder to central and southern counties.

The heaviest rainfall was in the mountains of Riverside and San Bernardino counties, where up to 68mm (2.67in) fell in a few hours. Further north, Death Valley ‚Äì famously one of the driest places on Earth ‚Äì received 15mm of rain, triple the average rainfall for September and a full quarter of the yearly average.

items.title: Fires in Spain and Portugal fueled by climate change
items.content_html: Wildfires caused devastation in Spain and Portugal this summer. Scientists say that rising global temperatures caused by burning fossil fuels has made the deadly fires 40 times more likely.

items.title: 'KPop Demon Hunters,' a Netflix hit upending stereotypes
items.content_html: A team of superheroes, not a girl group: The animated movie "KPop Demon Hunters" portrays K-pop idols as demon hunters filled with strength and self-determination.

items.title: Children in art: A journey through history
items.content_html: They've been immortalized on canvas as rulers, angels, or ragged but endearing street children. Why have children been depicted so differently across the centuries?

items.title: Desalination doesn't have to be bad for the environment
items.content_html: Drinking from the sea is essential to securing water supply but often has negative environmental impacts. Scientists say they can be minimized with careful planning and process.

items.title: William Kentridge show explores South African roots
items.content_html: With the world-renowned artist turning 70, a new German exhibition traces Kentridge's artistic evolution from the 1970s, and how colonialism and social division impacted his work.

items.title: Landslides and mudslides: Why they happen
items.content_html: Non-stop rain in Sudan caused a landslide to cover an entire village. The science of these natural disasters is simple. Preventing them is possible.

items.title: How humans made chickens grow and foxes shrink
items.content_html: Archeologists in southern France have studied bones spanning 8,000 years to reveal how humans caused domestic animals to grow in overall size, while wild animals shrank.

items.title: Digital taxes put US-EU trade talks under pressure
items.content_html: Trump is now threatening retaliation over EU tech rules, shaking the bloc‚Äôs 15% tariff deal. Lacking China‚Äôs rare earths leverage, Brussels is scrambling for countermeasures ‚Äî what cards can it still play?

items.title: 'The Haydn Expedition': A very democratic orchestra
items.content_html: The documentary film "The Haydn Expedition" tells the story of artistic and democratic freedom, and premiered at a special event in Hamburg.

items.title: Sex testing in athletics a setback to science?
items.content_html: Former Spanish hurdler Maria Jose Martinez-Patino knows better than most about genetic testing, having missed out on a chance at the Olympics as a result of it. She spoke to DW about World Athletics' new regulations.

items.title: Bundesliga: Leverkusen sack coach ten Hag after two games
items.content_html: Former Manchester United head coach Erik ten Hag has been sacked by Bayer Leverkusen after only 62 days in charge and one defeat.

items.title: Why some countries want fewer public holidays
items.content_html: Some governments have proposed reducing public holidays, claiming it helps budgets and boosts growth. However, counter-arguments suggest that productivity is not just about days worked and that time off is important.

items.title: Germany's road to 2026 World Cup begins: What to know
items.content_html: The German national team has six games to play in 2025. The plan is to win them all and secure early qualification for the 2026 FIFA World Cup, but injuries and struggles against top teams cast something of a shadow.

items.title: How much screen time is safe for children?
items.content_html: In a world full of smartphones, tablets, and computers, how much media time is acceptable at what stage of life? Though there's little data on the issue, there are still a few principles on which most experts agree.

items.title: 'Currydurst': Beer and curry ketchup in a glass
items.content_html: A new German beer with a curry ketchup flavor is set to test tastebuds as it celebrates Hamburg street food culture and tries to become another St. Pauli legend.

items.title: Taking the 'red pill': From meme to political ideology
items.content_html: Memes inspired by a cult sci-fi film have developed into a global subculture in which men claim their victimhood and promote misogyny online.

items.title: MLS star M√ºller settling in to 'village' life in Vancouver
items.content_html: Thomas M√ºller seems to be settling in well at the first club he has known apart from Bayern Munich. For a one-club man until a few weeks ago, he also seems to be truly embracing a new city and culture.

items.title: Nick Woltemade: Who is Germany's new Premier League star?
items.content_html: The young Germany striker, who was of great interest to Bayern Munich this summer, has left Stuttgart for Newcastle.

items.title: Dissident Belarusian sports official thought to be in Russia
items.content_html: Anatol Kotau has been unreachable for over a week. Those who know him suspect foul play, with the Belarusian secret service warning dissidents of retribution.

items.title: India vs. US: Who stands to lose most in the trade dispute?
items.content_html: US tariffs on Indian goods have risen to 50%, one of the highest rates in the world. The trade row between two of the world's biggest economies could have serious consequences for both.

items.title: Hurricane Katrina left lasting legacy for youngest survivors
items.content_html: Twenty years after Hurricane Katrina, survivors who lived through the storm as children are still reckoning with a city transformed ‚Äî and the stories of loss and trauma they never got to tell.

items.title: Why I tried antidepressants to treat my chronic pain
items.content_html: Antidepressants treat depression and other mental conditions. But some people say the drugs ease physical aches, too. The evidence, however, is sobering.

items.title: What Trump's Fed power play could mean for the US and global economies
items.content_html: US President Donald Trump's attempt to sack Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook has caused shockwaves. The move could fatally undermine the Fed's independence and have implications for the US and global economies.

items.title: German car industry sheds 51,500 jobs in a year
items.content_html: The dip equates to almost 7% of the total workforce in the German auto sector. Faltering exports to China and the US play a role, as new tariffs raise barriers to entry in both these core markets.

items.title: EuroBasket 2025: All you need to know
items.content_html: It's time for the European championship of basketball again. Here's all you need to know about the 2025 edition, one held in four different nations.

items.title: Africa's youth may feel lonelier than you know
items.content_html: Loneliness isn't often linked to Africa, but it is very common. Most affected are young people dealing with changing social and family structures.

items.title: Global water crisis could cost trillions
items.content_html: A growing water deficit driven by heat and drought is set to devastate local and national economies, resulting in food insecurity, displacement and political upheaval.

items.title: Olympic swimmer sees need for better Germany integration
items.content_html: Swimmer Alaa Maso fled Syria in 2015 and, along with around a million others, arrived in Germany. After competing at the Paris Olympics in 2024, Maso is applying to become a German citizen.

items.title: Nazi human experiments still influence medicine today
items.content_html: A new database tells the stories of victims of forced medical research during the Nazi era. What role do the specimens and findings from that time play in modern medicine and research?
